Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will partially support the program "Noncommutative Geometry Emphasis year" https://sites.math.northwestern.edu/~tamarkin/Emphasis/
at Northwestern University in the academic year 2018-2019. This program will include the mini-workshop "Recent developments in Topological Cyclic Homology" (https://sites.math.northwestern.edu/~tamarkin/Emphasis/Topcyc) and the conference "Modern Trends in Non-commutative Geometry" (https://sites.math.northwestern.edu/~tamarkin/Emphasis/Tsyganfest). The mini-workshop will be held on the weekend Nov 3-4, 2018 and the conference will be held during the week May 20-24 (Monday-Friday) in 2019. Both events will take place at Northwestern University in Evanston IL. The goal of this program is to promote interaction between researchers working in areas related to non-commutative geometry. The mini-workshop and the conference will provide opportunities for researchers to disseminate their ideas and to broaden their perspectives. They will also provide opportunities for graduate students and postdocs to interact with senior experts in the areas related to noncommutative geometry.

Noncommutative geometry is connected to many branches of mathematics and mathematical physics and the main idea of noncommutative geometry is to study geometry via algebras of functions on "noncommutative manifolds". On such a "noncommutative manifold", the relevant object is no longer the space of points, but rather an associative algebra, which may be noncommutative. The topics of the program will include: noncommutative Hodge theory, (topological) cyclic/Hochschild homology, K-theory, index theory, deformation quantization, Riemann-Hilbert correspondence and microlocal categories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the conference "Modern Trends in Non-Commutative Geometry". This conference took place in May 2019 at Northwestern University and it was a part of the year long program "Emphasis Year in Non-Commutative Geometry". This year long program was partially supported by the Department of Mathematics of Northwestern University. 


The conference "Modern Trends in Non-Commutative Geometry"  featured 27 talks of experts from the US and abroad in noncommutative geometry and related fields. Participants were exposed to a fascinating mixture of topics. Some of these topics involve very abstract concepts: topological Hochschild/cyclic homology, derived algebraic geometry, operads and their generalizations, string topology and even ring spectra while others touched rather concrete mathematical objects of classical nature: knots, character varieties of Riemann surfaces, symplectic singularities, moduli spaces and integrable systems. 
There were over 52 participants from the US, Belgium, France, Russia, Switzerland and the UK.The conference was a successful networking event which promoted further progress in noncommutative geometry and related fields.

Many recent results in noncommutative geometry and related fields were presented at this conference. Participants had stimulating discussions and the conference promoted further progress in this fascinating area of mathematics.

Key outcomes include completed papers and preprints as well as preprints in preparation written by the participants of this conference.
